verses.text: Then all Israel gathered at Hebron to David and said, 'Look, we are your flesh and bone.'
verses.comment: The phrase 'flesh and bone' emphasizes deep kinship and unity among God's people, foreshadowing the unity of the body of Christ (cf. Eph. 5:30).

verses.text: Even when Saul was king, it was you who led Israel out and brought them in. And the LORD your God said to you, 'You will shepherd My people Israel, and you will be ruler over My people Israel.'
verses.comment: God appoints David as shepherd, combining kingly rule with pastoral care—an image that anticipates Christ, the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).

verses.text: So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and David made a covenant with them at Hebron before the LORD. Then they anointed David king over Israel, as the LORD had promised through Samuel.
verses.comment: The anointing of David is a public, sacramental affirmation of his kingship, illustrating how God uses physical signs to confer spiritual reality; an echo of holy rites established for leadership.

verses.text: Then David and all Israel went to Jerusalem, that is Jebus; the Jebusites, the inhabitants of the land, were there.
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s earlier name, Jebus, highlights its conquest and sanctification; the city would become the spiritual center of God's people.

verses.text: The inhabitants of Jebus said to David, 'You will not enter here.' But David captured the stronghold of Zion, which is now called the city of David.
verses.comment: David's triumph over Jebus prefigures the spiritual victory of the Messiah, who establishes His kingdom where resistance once seemed impossible.

verses.text: David said, 'Whoever attacks the Jebusites first will become chief and commander.' Joab son of Zeruiah went up first, so he became chief.
verses.comment: Joab's leadership is rewarded through merit, demonstrating how God calls and elevates those who are bold in service—a principle that governs spiritual leadership.

verses.text: And David lived in the stronghold; therefore it was called the city of David.
verses.comment: David residing in Jerusalem sets this city apart as the chosen dwelling of God's anointed—a holy city whose significance continues throughout salvation history.

verses.text: David built the city all around, from the Millo inward, and Joab restored the rest of the city.
verses.comment: This verse describes the establishment of sacred space; the building and restoration of Jerusalem prefigure the spiritual building up of the new people of God (1 Peter 2:5).

verses.text: And David grew greater and greater, for the LORD of hosts was with him.
verses.comment: David’s growth is attributed to the presence of the Lord. God’s blessing upon faithful leaders is a theme echoed in the life and ministry of Christ.

verses.text: Now these are the chief men of David’s mighty warriors, who joined him in his kingdom with all Israel to make him king, according to the word of the LORD concerning Israel.
verses.comment: David’s rule is supported by loyal, courageous followers. The bond between David and his men prefigures the communion of saints joined in sacrificial unity.

verses.text: This is the list of David’s mighty warriors: Jashobeam, a Hachmonite, chief of the Three; he raised his spear against three hundred whom he killed at one time.
verses.comment: Extraordinary feats of valor, like Jashobeam’s, show God’s power working through human instruments for the benefit of His people.

verses.text: After him was Eleazar, son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the three mighty warriors.
verses.comment: Jewish tradition holds these men in special honor—an image of those uniquely set apart for spiritual combat and defense of the faith.

verses.text: He was with David at Pas-dammim when the Philistines were gathered there for battle. At a field full of barley, the troops fled before the Philistines.
verses.comment: Standing firm in adversity, Eleazar exhibits the faithfulness and courage expected of those who will not abandon the field, symbolizing steadfastness in spiritual life.

verses.text: But they took their stand in the middle of the field, defended it, and struck down the Philistines; and the LORD brought about a great victory.
verses.comment: God brings victory to those who stand firm—His grace is the source of every triumph, just as the spiritual battles of the faithful culminate in God’s will.

verses.text: Three of the thirty chief warriors went down to the rock, to David at the cave of Adullam, while a company of Philistines was camped in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.comment: Adullam is a place of refuge, representing the need for a spiritual sanctuary in times of trial—an image later perfected by Christ as our true refuge.

verses.text: David was then in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was at Bethlehem.
verses.comment: Bethlehem, site of the enemy’s garrison, is later the birthplace of the Messiah, pointing to the transformation of places of conflict into places of hope.

verses.text: David longed and said, 'Oh that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem, which is by the gate!'
verses.comment: David’s thirst points to the spiritual longing that only God can satisfy; it recalls the living water Christ offers in the Gospel (John 4:14).

verses.text: So the three broke through the camp of the Philistines, drew water from the well at Bethlehem by the gate, took it, and brought it to David. But David would not drink it; instead, he poured it out to the LORD.
verses.comment: David’s pouring out the water underscores the principle of offering the best sacrifices to God, pointing to self-giving devotion.

verses.text: He said, 'Far be it from me, before my God, that I should do this. Should I drink the blood of these men who risked their lives? For at the risk of their lives they brought it.' So he would not drink it. These things the three mighty warriors did.
verses.comment: David equates the water with the blood of those who sacrificed for him, hinting at the profound respect for sacrificial offerings—a theme later developed in the new covenant’s sacramental life.

verses.text: Abishai, brother of Joab, was chief of the Thirty. He raised his spear against three hundred and killed them, and won a name among the Thirty.
verses.comment: Abishai’s valor earns him distinction among the mighty, highlighting God’s recognition of courage and faithfulness.

verses.text: He was more highly honored than the Thirty and became their commander, but he did not attain to the Three.
verses.comment: Acknowledgment of hierarchy within David’s warriors reflects the divine order and structure established for governance of the people.

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was a courageous man from Kabzeel, who performed great exploits. He killed two lion-like men of Moab, and he also went down into a pit and killed a lion on a snowy day.
verses.comment: Benaiah’s feats recall earlier acts of faith and courage—mirroring how God works in and through His chosen servants.

verses.text: He also killed an Egyptian, a man of great stature, five cubits tall. The Egyptian had a spear like a weaver’s beam, but Benaiah went down to him with a staff, snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand, and killed him with his own spear.
verses.comment: Benaiah’s deed echoes David’s earlier defeat of Goliath, signifying the triumph of faith over intimidation by worldly power.

verses.text: These things Benaiah son of Jehoiada did, and he won a name among the Thirty.
verses.comment: Recognition is given for heroic deeds, reminding us of the reward kept by God for those who serve Him faithfully.

verses.text: He was more honored than the Thirty, but he did not reach the Three. And David put him over his guard.
verses.comment: Elevation to a position of trust reflects God’s ordering of leadership roles within the community for the good of all.

verses.text: The mighty warriors were: Asahel the brother of Joab, Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem,
verses.comment: The listing of names signals the importance of communal memory and honoring those set apart for noteworthy service.

verses.text: Shammoth the Harorite, Helez the Pelonite,
verses.comment: Many names here have minor differences in spelling compared to parallel texts, reflecting alternate traditions in oral transmission.

verses.text: Ira son of Ikesh the Tekoite, Abiezer the Anathothite,
verses.comment: Each member of David’s retinue is individually recognized, underscoring the value of every person in God’s work.

verses.text: Sibbecai the Hushathite, Ilai the Ahohite,
verses.comment: Slight variations in names between Chronicles and Samuel showcase complementary historical accounts.

verses.text: Maharai the Netophathite, Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite,
verses.comment: The repetition of geographic locations shows the wide reach of David’s influence—a kingdom gathered from all corners, like the universal church.

verses.text: Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah of the people of Benjamin, Benaiah the Pirathonite,
verses.comment: Gibeah, Benjamin’s city, had a storied past—David’s kingdom now embraces and reconciles old rivalries.

verses.text: Hurai from the brooks of Gaash, Abiel the Arbathite,
verses.comment: Many names and places seem obscure, but Scripture preserves them to show God’s knowledge and care of every individual.

verses.text: Azmaveth the Baharumite, Eliahba the Shaalbonite,
verses.comment: Each location is a testament to the spread of the kingdom—a foreshadow of the church’s mission to all nations.

verses.text: The sons of Hashem the Gizonite, Jonathan son of Shagee the Hararite,
verses.comment: Family lineages are remembered, showing the communal and familial nature of life among God's people.

verses.text: Ahiam son of Sacar the Hararite, Eliphal son of Ur,
verses.comment: The preservation of names—whether prominent or obscure—signals the importance of each soul in God’s plan.

verses.text: Hepher the Mecherathite, Ahijah the Pelonite,
verses.comment: Maintaining these records affirms a tradition of reverence for the forebears of faith.

verses.text: Hezro the Carmelite, Naarai son of Ezbai,
verses.comment: The diversity of backgrounds foreshadows a kingdom not limited by one tribe or tongue, but open to all the faithful.

verses.text: Joel the brother of Nathan, Mibhar son of Hagri,
verses.comment: God’s people are built of many members—each contributes to the building up of the whole.

verses.text: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah,
verses.comment: Foreigners like the Ammonite Zelek are included, showing the openness of David’s kingdom—a sign of God’s covenant extending beyond Israel.

verses.text: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
verses.comment: The inclusion of these names points to the value of each individual regardless of fame or status.

verses.text: Uriah the Hittite, Zabad son of Ahlai,
verses.comment: Uriah's name evokes later events with David, ultimately underscoring themes of repentance and mercy, foundational in spiritual growth.

verses.text: Adina son of Shiza the Reubenite, chief of the Reubenites, and thirty with him,
verses.comment: Tribal distinctions remain significant—David’s reign draws unity from diversity, mirroring the spiritual unity of God’s people.

verses.text: Hanan son of Maacah, Joshaphat the Mithnite,
verses.comment: Such detailed lists preserve the memory of those whose faithfulness formed the foundation for the coming Messianic hope.

verses.text: Uzzia the Ashterathite, Shama and Jeiel the sons of Hotham the Aroerite,
verses.comment: Through the record of these individuals, we see the principle that all who belong to God’s kingdom have value and purpose.

verses.text: Jediael son of Shimri, Joha his brother the Tizite,
verses.comment: Family relationships are highlighted, pointing to the inheritance of faith handed down generation to generation.

verses.text: Eliel the Mahavite, Jeribai and Joshaviah sons of Elnaam, Ithmah the Moabite,
verses.comment: The presence of Moabites and other non-Israelites in the list reinforces the idea of God’s grace opening salvation to peoples outside initial covenant boundaries.

verses.text: Eliel, Obed, and Jaasiel the Mezobaite.
verses.comment: The enumeration concludes, a witness that the kingdom is composed of many, united under one anointed king, prefiguring the unity of the faithful under the Messiah.
